TextBlock.TextLine: In Antwerpen 9 Juny 1681
Brussel Juff Bonnecroy
naer dat gisteren aen ul heb gest hebbe het packen canten ontf, & sal het exam
ul moet voor mij besorgen de hoogh raill wercken, renise gront, volgens
het monster aen ul gelaten, segge volgens de mate ul gesonden, soo gelieft
het ten eersten te besorgen, icq sal miet goets pesie naeste weeke bij ul
sijn, gelieft van als wat gereet te maecken, daer en tussen, en manq. niet
af te seynden de hooghe crawat canten, soo wel raille aes venise gront
soo haest die gereet sijn, sonder naer mij te waghten
In Antw: 9 Juny 1681
Megoelen meiuff wigans
meinff Den ul van 6 deser met de canten ontfangen sende aen ul wederom
6 stuken te weten, 6 a a ƒ3 a a 58 a 6 a 46: a 3 ¼ a ƒ7 en 10¼ a 46
en 5 ¼ a 150, open gront endient mij niet oock crasen
canten leeger als de mate ul gelaten, en mach ick niet koopen, soo waert
dat de a 3½ traille werck hoogh genoeghwaren soude die wel begeiren, alsoo
ick veel crawat warch van die hooghde moet hebben soo in venise als traille
gront ende de lenghde moeten sijn a 4 oft &oft 12 al met vieren differende
heb soo mij dunckt a 6 meer gevonden als op ue noticie staet, soo gelieft
mij de Rek op het aldernaerste te senden vant geene hier gehouden hebben
soo ul traillie en renise grout werke genoegh hadde soude wel wat
meerder Begeren terwijlen Blijve
10 In Antw: 19 Juny
London Pichering H Robinson
th 2
msssr. I have before mee yd of 27 pass. with acctt & pattarn for 5 bales of goods
bought & provided att leeds & schipt aboard John nelson att Hull forour
acctt. in compa for my ½ in which I have given you creditt, & accepted
yd bills for the valew thought I could have wished you had drawne sess
in consideration of the goods I have brought for you according to the
inclosed invoyce & acctt curitt bij which is due tomee £210:0:5 ½ for
which pray remitt mee the valew: the bale of tykes & N.15 hath been
reshipt here aboardabeurtman for gent & then reschipt againe for
Bruges which makes the undermost charges which are gafed when wee
can ship heredire otely for london the goods are the very best that
can be hadd for mony, begides thread beeng much risen will make the
tykes rise att least 10 styvers & 15 pr peece which you may observe & not
sell y without proffitt to content you may be sure to have y with the
first English vessel, nott beeng yett att bruges. I have had no time yett to
ex amm the in voyce of the 5 bales you sent, butt for the patt. they are
not to thene I sent for enstouctions the first of marck, principelly in
the modecolleurs which are not att all observed thought that is most
necessary I hope the goods may prove the better which bj the patte I do
not promised my self yett god sending them safe either to ostend or
brugges which is one the same & then here, shall be able to given you
my opinion whilst I exspect the bill of lrading & yd remises remaine
In Antwerp 11 Juny 1681
London, John Loyd
Sr. I wrott you the yt curitt that yd pack of legaturen MN.1 are att brugges
exspecting the opportunitie of an English vessel to be sent to you which now
are dayly exspected : tought to have sent you an invoyce this day, butt the maker
sending an inperfect fortory of the 2p. of linnen vripp & sharges besides
not hoveing them from Brugges, so have dilayd sending itt you till next whilst
I have been in disbours some time for you & straightned for mony have this day
drawne on you in my bill payable to mr. Henrg Maynard £100: att 36:6
att 2 uso which please to honoer with acceptance & pass to acctt. accordingly
thought itt is litte more then this pack will come to yett shall make
itt you good to content. in case you have yett any tykesinsold be not to much
in laste to sell them because thread is risen considerably in so much that by all
apearence the tjkes will rise 10 a 15 stivers ap where in Iean serve you freely
command mee that a
London Henry Maynard
In Antwarp 15 Juny 1681
h
Sr. my last to you was on the 4 curit sence recd. yd of 27 past I have that our
goode are shipt before this time & that the Euglish vessels may come forward very
speedly: I observe what you say of the G.N. silver marck, pray do as much you
can to procure 5 peeces the sooner the better: there is butt 4 bales to be shipped
so you had don as well to have added the resting spa cloathes whoever as you thiugh
best drap cullours are much demandes whene fore trekon that the frises must
be all of sundry drap cullours, the livelier, the better, because Dull cullours
will be not so propper if you please lett mee have some patt. & Ill presently a
advise you the need full & if you should buy any could desire you to make a patd
book of each bale like you are used to do with the cloathes, for I supose
is
to sell y bij the patt. not to open them before needs must be Iam gladd you
remember my packing press lett good order & lare betaken that itt be well kept
& no where broaken: in closed my bill for £100: att 2 uso att 35:6 in my
owne bill for yd acctt on mr. John loyd for which please to procure the needfull
as also to afford mee yd opinion of him though I have butt now & then smalle
imploy from him I shall remitt for my acctt. att shithir time in closed acctt
of sale of may last, which please to examintt finding urigh note in
conformitie: I observe againe the recommendations of m. slaughter
concerning the bussynes of mr. Peeters. I have wrott him severall timee
& they give mee no answer attall, they leave all things, as if they were not
in
concerned: the goods in the whare house of mad. Bouwens sell dayly by the cande
thoughs to patt off those of JB there butt the yallow cullours will yeald
little or no mory, so that I am att aloss, imless I might returne them for
England, or that IP. be able to finde out some other meanes to procure satis=
faction, butt he is not like toline any longer the heires of mad. bouwens
will keep the goods you sent up on their accompt, so that is not to be altered
the desirong to know where the bayes be you will be remboursed as I suposed
about 3: or 4 weekes hence, butt if you wanted mony, you could butt draw
up on the heires as mr. vandall hath don which keep to yd self leaving you to
do discresion remaine
11 june 1681
London Arthur Hineslay
th
S. accordingly I wrott you the 31: past have advise from mr. Collier to have payd you
£70st for my acctt. I shall remitt you mone p next very first noward my half
in the rest of the in ordered goods which I hope are ready & shipt by this time att Exon
of which pray give mee yd timely advise the bales N. 13: 24 are with mee & sold
the bale N.13 of which the cullours were all good so do returne you the pattarnes
that you please to order mr. wood to provide an ther such bale, besides one
more assorted with i5 grajes most stone graijes & steel grayes & is of the
in closed mode cols. so that will be 60p in all 22 yd serges besides one bale
to cont. 15 cloth serges 22 yd broad ayd or or then about of 48: to5 ofs ap and
15 serges 24g of these pattarnes also good goods, so emitt no prices butt desires
to be well served this recommand sas to yd care & expedition whilst
these pats returne the same to provide
1Bale conr. 30 seges 3 30 p of the same sorts mone bale 22 yd
in an other bale
l
15 of the same Eucleurs
13„ grajes stone & steel
50p ou an other of 22yds
in cont
15 cloth serges of 45 a 50 p
13 caryes 24 gard of the best sort al
l
1 to cond . 30 sarges of these Callours in an other bal
